Governance demands
The Student Council has dramatically responded to the
undergraduate's crucial need for a potent. and effective
system of governance. Action at Monday's meeting, which
curtails all cooperation between the Sc and the
administration until the resolution of the governance issue,
has once and for all established governance reform as the
prime target of undergraduate (and hopefully Student
Council) action.
What the Council's move means, in effect, is
that they will continue to deal with the administration in
an effort to determine the direction the new governance
system will take, but they will not cooperate in any other
area. This will hardly cripple the Homewood
administration, but it may well serve to make the
seriousness of the undergraduate demands known to those
in power.
Not only did the Council illustrate that governance is
the key issue for undergraduates, they have sketched the
outline which that system utmost take. The over-riding
demand is that students be given a policy-making power.
Undergraduates will no longer be content to serve a merely
advisory function. The SC demands, as students must, that
the new governing body have a definitive voice in
determining departmental course loads, class scheduling,
course validity, and faculty tenure and advancement
procedures. These are the basics; students must first
define, then demand the coming system.
Unity among undergraduates, in stating their demands
and following them up with real action, will prove to be
the crucial factor in the coming confrontation. The
administration is committed to the idea of undergraduates
as nothing more than advisors in the running of the
University. They will not change that commitment
without considerable pressure from students..
The Student Council has taken the first major action on
behalf of governance reform this year, but it is no more
than that. The Council has taken first steps before, only to
stumble long before reaching their goal.
One of the first ways undergraduates can show support
for the Council's action (and the demand for a University.
government which reflects our position here) is to turn the
upcoming Youngbloods concert into a success. The
Council is running the concert completely without
administration assistance, and it important that students
show that they will support a student-run affair. Failure to
do so will only weaken student demands, and strenghten
the hand of the administration.

Governance demands
The Student Council has dramatically responded to the
undergraduate's crucial need for a potent. and effective
system of governance. Action at Monday's meeting, which
curtails all cooperation between the Sc and the
administration until the resolution of the governance issue,
has once and for all established governance reform as the
prime target of undergraduate (and hopefully Student
Council) action.
What the Council's move means, in effect, is
that they will continue to deal with the administration in
an effort to determine the direction the new governance
system will take, but they will not cooperate in any other
area. This will hardly cripple the Homewood
administration, but it may well serve to make the
seriousness of the undergraduate demands known to those
in power.
Not only did the Council illustrate that governance is
the key issue for undergraduates, they have sketched the
outline which that system utmost take. The over-riding
demand is that students be given a policy-making power.
Undergraduates will no longer be content to serve a merely
advisory function. The SC demands, as students must, that
the new governing body have a definitive voice in
determining departmental course loads, class scheduling,
course validity, and faculty tenure and advancement
procedures. These are the basics; students must first
define, then demand the coming system.
Unity among undergraduates, in stating their demands
and following them up with real action, will prove to be
the crucial factor in the coming confrontation. The
administration is committed to the idea of undergraduates
as nothing more than advisors in the running of the
University. They will not change that commitment
without considerable pressure from students..
The Student Council has taken the first major action on
behalf of governance reform this year, but it is no more
than that. The Council has taken first steps before, only to
stumble long before reaching their goal.
One of the first ways undergraduates can show support
for the Council's action (and the demand for a University.
government which reflects our position here) is to turn the
upcoming Youngbloods concert into a success. The
Council is running the concert completely without
administration assistance, and it important that students
show that they will support a student-run affair. Failure to
do so will only weaken student demands, and strenghten
the hand of the administration.
